qas.question: What did Aristotle believe about a void?
What was historically disputed about vacuums?

answers.text: whether such a thing as a vacuum can exist.

qas.question: What did something that was literally nothing at all,According to Plato, mean?

answers.text: cannot rightly be said to exist

qas.question: Aristotle thought what would fill any rarity that might give rise to a void?
What did Greek philosophers believe could not occur naturally?
What language was spoken by Plato?
What did Aristotle believe were the fundamental elements of understanding physics?
What can an atom not be understood by according to Greek philosophers?
What did Ancient Greek philosophers believe atoms could not do?

context: Historically, there has been much dispute over <a1_0>whether such a thing as a vacuum can exist.<a1_0/> <b5_0>Ancient Greek<b5_0/> philosophers debated the existence of a vacuum, or void, in the context of atomism, which posited <b6_0>void and atom<b6_0/> as the fundamental explanatory elements of physics. Following Plato, even the abstract concept of a featureless void faced considerable skepticism: it could not be apprehended by <b7_0>the senses<b7_0/>, it could not, itself, provide additional explanatory power beyond the physical volume with which it was commensurate and, by definition, it was quite literally nothing at all, which <a2_0>cannot rightly be said to <b8_0>exist<b8_0/><a2_0/>. Aristotle believed that <a0_0><b4_0>no void<b4_0/> could occur naturally,<a0_0/> because the <a3_0>denser surrounding material continuum<a3_0/> would immediately fill any incipient rarity that might give rise to a void.
